awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NSF-BSF: WoU-MMA: Crossing the Chasm: From Compact Object Mergers to Cosmic Fireworks
awd_abstract_narration:
The project will model the evolution of matter outflows following the merger of neutron star binaries. The project will stitch together the results from simulations that are valid at different scales, using the output of smaller scale simulations as the input for larger scale simulations. In this way, the project will be able to follow the matter outflows and jets from the initial merger event all the way out to the point where the material interacts with the interstellar medium. The project will be able to predict the electromagnetic signals from the merger and relate them to the initial properties of the binary system. The project will also develop materials for use in public outreach to bring astronomy education to students in kindergarten through high school. This award advances the goals of the Windows on the Universe Big Idea. This project is supported by both the National Science Foundation and the US-Israel Binational Science Foundation to further collaborations between the astrophysical communities in the two countries. 

The project will start with final snapshots from general relativity simulations of the merger event as initial conditions for general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic (GRMHD) simulations. Similarly, the final snapshots of the GRMHD simulations will be used as initial conditions for the magnetohydrodynamic (MHD) simulations that carry the jets out to distances where it interacts with the interstellar medium. The project will then calculate electromagnetic signals from the simulation results using a radiative transfer code. The simulations will be run on GPUs for increased computational efficiency. The project will also develop "Star Packs" for the Sacramento Library appropriate for K-5 students that can be checked out in libraries. The PI at Purdue will develop instructional materials on gravity and black holes for middle- and high-school students. The Northwestern PI will develop instructional materials for an electro-magnetism class at the high-school level.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The detection of gravitational waves has revolutionized astronomy, opening a new way to observe cosmic events and combining different types of signals in what is known as multi-messenger astronomy. One of the most significant events in this field was the detection of GW170817, the merger of two neutron stars, which was not only detected by gravitational wave observatories but also by telescopes that captured its electromagnetic counterpart. This event provided a unique insight into what happens after such mergers, including the formation of a relativistic jet and the ejection of slower-moving material, both of which produced the electromagnetic signals detected.

The importance of GW170817 to multi-messenger astronomy cannot be overstated, as it was the first event where both gravitational waves and electromagnetic signals were observed from the same source. This has led to a deeper understanding of the processes involved in the aftermath of neutron star mergers, but questions remain about how exactly these different signals are connected. The goal of this research is to bridge the gap between the compact object merger, which produces gravitational waves, and the electromagnetic signals that follow, by using advanced simulations that model the physics involved at different stages and scales.

Numerical relativity simulations allow scientists to predict the gravitational wave signals produced during these mergers and to understand the conditions of the gas surrounding the merging objects immediately afterward. However, electromagnetic signals, such as light, X-rays, and gamma rays, are generated by the interaction of the material ejected during the merger with the surrounding environment, and these signals are detected far from their source. This research project aims to connect the two—the gravitational wave data from the moment of the merger and the subsequent electromagnetic emissions—by using state-of-the-art numerical simulations that model the behavior of the material ejected during the merger as it moves away from the center of the event.

To do this, the researchers use the final snapshots from general relativity (GR) simulations, which describe the moment of the merger, as the starting conditions for their GRMHD (general relativistic magnetohydrodynamic) simulations. These simulations are able to track the evolution of the jet and the outflows from the merger as they move outward. Once these simulations reach their limit, the researchers use the final outputs as the starting point for another set of simulations—relativistic MHD models—that will follow the jet and outflows even farther, to the point where they interact with the external medium. This multi-step approach will allow the team to model how electromagnetic signals are produced from all components of the post-merger system.

The intellectual contributions of this research are significant, with the Purdue team producing several key publications that advance the project’s goals. For example, they participated in the first 3D simulations of gamma-ray burst jets from their formation around a black hole to the point where they emit observable light. Other studies from the team focused on kilonova emission, which is the light produced by the radioactive decay of heavy elements created in neutron star mergers, and on modeling the gamma-ray burst energy produced by these events. The team has also developed a new tool called "jetsimpy," which models the afterglow emission from gamma-ray bursts and is now available to the broader scientific community for further research.

Broader impacts of the project extend into public outreach and education. The principal investigator, Giannios, has led several events aimed at high school students and teachers, with a focus on explaining key astrophysical concepts such as the Doppler effect and its role in measuring the expansion of the universe. These events have been part of Purdue University’s "Saturday Morning Astrophysics Program" and have received positive feedback from participants. Giannios has also developed educational activities that teach students how to measure the mass of black holes and explain fundamental concepts of general relativity, black holes, and gravitational waves. Due to the success of these programs, they are planned to continue in the coming year.

In addition to these outreach efforts, the project has provided research opportunities for undergraduate students, helping to foster the next generation of scientists. Through this combination of cutting-edge research and community engagement, the project is helping to deepen our understanding of the universe while inspiring and educating the public.
